scopecontent.p: A handwritten letter in French from Frederic Bartholdi to Louis-Oscar Roty suggesting nine different texts to be put on the medal commemorating the gift of the Statue of Liberty to the United States from France.

note.p: Numismatic sketches are visible on the verso.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Frédéric Bartholdi was a French sculptor best known for designing Liberty Enlightening the World, commonly known as the Statue of Liberty. To celebrate the relationship between France and the United States, the Union Franco-Americaine (Franco-American Union) was established in 1874. It raised money to build a massive statue to celebrate this relationship and Bartholdi was given the job. In October 1886, the structure was officially presented as the joint gift of the French and American people, and installed on Bedloe's Island in New York Harbor.
Louis-Oscar Roty was one of the most celebrated medallists of the Art Nouveau period. He created a medal for the Union Franco Americaine in 1886, commemorating the gift of the Statue of Liberty.
